node.title: Dramatic video shows jet skid off runaway and split in half
node.description: The accident temporarily caused operations to shut down at the country's biggest airport, impacting hundreds of flights.

node.title: Nissan, NASA teaming on "game changing" electric vehicle batteries
node.description: Nissan says they'll be so stable they could be used in pacemakers. The Japanese giant says the all-solid-state battery will replace the lithium-ion battery now in use and promises to charge much more quickly and be lighter yet safe.

node.title: Ferrero recalls Kinder chocolates in U.S. over Salmonella fears
node.description: The move follows recalls earlier in the week in the U.K. and several European countries over concerns around products from a Belgian  factory, though the bacteria haven't been found in any Kinder products yet.

node.title: Mother accused of drowning her baby and toddler in bathtub
node.description: The children's father returned home when his wife "allegedly told him that she had hurt the children," authorities said.

node.title: Men accused of impersonating federal agents investigated for possible Iranian intelligence ties
node.description: The two are scheduled for a detention hearing today.

node.title: Widow used GoFundMe proceeds to buy gifts for husband's alleged killer
node.description: After Jamie Faith was gunned down, his wife Jennifer bought her husband's alleged shooter airline tickets and a large screen TV, and gave him use of her credit cards.

node.title: How to watch SpaceX launch first private crew to space station
node.description: The Axiom-1 flight carries a crew of four private citizens, with a former NASA astronaut as mission commander.

node.title: Jamie Faith murder: Unraveling the plot
node.description: In 2020, the American Airlines manager was gunned down during a morning walk with his wife and dog. Two years later, his wife, Jennifer, pleaded guilty for her role in orchestrating his death.

node.title: Man convicted of setting wildfire that killed dozen California condors
node.description: Ivan Gomez, 31, was convicted by a judge of starting the August 2020 150,000 Big Sur Dolan fire that also endangered the lives of 14 firefighters who had use emergency shelters. Three were hospitalized.

node.title: South Carolina schedules first execution with firing squad ready
node.description: Richard Bernard Moore, 57, could face a choice between the electric chair and the firing squad.

node.title: World food prices at all-time high due to Ukraine war, U.N. says
node.description: One official of the world body calls it "remarkable." The measure rose 12.6% from February's record mark.

node.title: Pilots threatened after online conspiracy blames them for deadly floods
node.description: As floods swept away homes and cars in Australia, online rumors claimed an aviation company documenting the damage was dropping chemicals to "activate rain."

node.title: New particle measurement contradicts understanding of universe
node.description: The W boson is an electrically charged fundamental particle that governs one of the four fundamental forces of nature.

node.title: Dozens killed in attack on train station in east Ukraine
node.description: Around 4000 mostly women and children were at the station at the time of the attack, the mayor of Kramatorsk said.

node.title: Sungjae Im leads at Masters; Tiger Woods opens under par
node.description: With the galleries at Augusta National Golf Club following his every move, Tiger Woods made his long-anticipated return to competitive golf at the Masters.

node.title: Tourist dies after 250-foot fall from cliff on treacherous Hawaii trail
node.description: Officials have tried to stop the spread of online videos luring people to the steep ridges of the mountain range.

node.title: Ammon Bundy gets jail term for "making a mockery" of a prior sentence
node.description: The well-known antigovernment activist had been sentenced for trespassing at the Idaho Statehouse, where he was protesting anti-pandemic steps.

node.title: David Miliband on Ukraine's humanitarian crisis - "The Takeout"
node.description: Host Major Garrett talks with Miliband, a former U.K. foreign secretary, about war crimes and the humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.

node.title: Singapore jails Australian for hurling wine bottle, killing man
node.description: The judge called the incident which also injured the victim's wife an act of religious hostility toward Muslims.

node.title: Pink Floyd releases first single in decades, to support Ukraine
node.description: All proceeds from "Hey Hey Rise Up" will go toward Ukrainian humanitarian relief efforts.

node.title: The red mist: Super Rugby's big problem
node.description: Opinion - With five red cards issued during a single weekend, it's hard to agree they are an effective deterrent, writes Jamie Wall.

node.title: Russia 'blacklists' Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern from entering country
node.description: Russia has released a 'blacklist' of New Zealand figures, including Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and all other MPs, banning them from entering the country.

node.title: Israeli forces kill Palestinian man sought over attack on Tel Aviv bar
node.description: Officials say the man with no clear affiliation to any terror group entered Israel illegally from the occupied West Bank before shooting into the crowded bar, killing 2.

node.title: Score! Carter gets his kicks for charity - 1598 of them
node.description: All Black and Crusaders legend Dan Carter has just completed a 24-hour kickathon in an effort to raise funds for children across New Zealand and the Pacific.

node.title: 'Made a bad situation worse': Russia tariffs set to hit fertiliser prices
node.description: Farmers will face increased costs for fertiliser as global demand is affected by import bans and tariff hikes imposed on Russia.

node.title: Thousands of greater Sydney residents affected by flood evacuations
node.description: More than 2000 people have been affected by evacuation orders across Sydney, and one man has been found drowned in his car.

node.title: Week in Politics: Settings, sanctions and Ashley Bloomfield
node.description: Analysis - The PM decides the country will stay in red for a while longer, the government ramps up sanctions against Russia but the opposition wants more, and Ashley Bloomfield resigns.

node.title: High Court rules vaccine mandates justified for doctors, teachers
node.description: A legal challenge questioning the lawfulness of the government's Covid-19 vaccination mandate for educators and health workers has failed in the High Court.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 9906 new cases and 10 further deaths, including one under 19
node.description: Ten new deaths have been reported today - including someone aged between 10-19 - while the daily number of new community cases in New Zealand has dropped back below the 10,000 mark.

node.title: 'At the moment, we're scared': KiwiRail yard gets thumbs-up but residents worried
node.description: A huge new rail yard proposed for the outskirts of Palmerston North is a step closer to reality. Affected residents are unhappy, but KiwiRail says the yards are much needed.
